title: Exploratory Data Analysis in R
text:
Hello! Today I will be performing Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) on a sample dataset “Boston” to find the characteristics of this dataset containing housing information for housing located in the Boston area. After performing EDA, I will create a simple linear model and make a prediction on a sample record of the median house value of an area.

library(ISLR2)

Warning: package 'ISLR2' was built under R version 4.3.2

mydata <- ISLR2::Boston
head(mydata)

     crim zn indus chas   nox    rm  age    dis rad tax ptratio lstat medv
1 0.00632 18  2.31    0 0.538 6.575 65.2 4.0900   1 296    15.3  4.98 24.0
2 0.02731  0  7.07    0 0.469 6.421 78.9 4.9671   2 242    17.8  9.14 21.6
3 0.02729  0  7.07    0 0.469 7.185 61.1 4.9671   2 242    17.8  4.03 34.7
4 0.03237  0  2.18    0 0.458 6.998 45.8 6.0622   3 222    18.7  2.94 33.4
5 0.06905  0  2.18    0 0.458 7.147 54.2 6.0622   3 222    18.7  5.33 36.2
6 0.02985  0  2.18    0 0.458 6.430 58.7 6.0622   3 222    18.7  5.21 28.7



summary(mydata)

      crim                zn             indus            chas        
 Min.   : 0.00632   Min.   :  0.00   Min.   : 0.46   Min.   :0.00000  
 1st Qu.: 0.08205   1st Qu.:  0.00   1st Qu.: 5.19   1st Qu.:0.00000  
 Median : 0.25651   Median :  0.00   Median : 9.69   Median :0.00000  
 Mean   : 3.61352   Mean   : 11.36   Mean   :11.14   Mean   :0.06917  
 3rd Qu.: 3.67708   3rd Qu.: 12.50   3rd Qu.:18.10   3rd Qu.:0.00000  
 Max.   :88.97620   Max.   :100.00   Max.   :27.74   Max.   :1.00000  
      nox               rm             age              dis        
 Min.   :0.3850   Min.   :3.561   Min.   :  2.90   Min.   : 1.130  
 1st Qu.:0.4490   1st Qu.:5.886   1st Qu.: 45.02   1st Qu.: 2.100  
 Median :0.5380   Median :6.208   Median : 77.50   Median : 3.207  
 Mean   :0.5547   Mean   :6.285   Mean   : 68.57   Mean   : 3.795  
 3rd Qu.:0.6240   3rd Qu.:6.623   3rd Qu.: 94.08   3rd Qu.: 5.188  
 Max.   :0.8710   Max.   :8.780   Max.   :100.00   Max.   :12.127  
      rad              tax           ptratio          lstat      
 Min.   : 1.000   Min.   :187.0   Min.   :12.60   Min.   : 1.73  
 1st Qu.: 4.000   1st Qu.:279.0   1st Qu.:17.40   1st Qu.: 6.95  
 Median : 5.000   Median :330.0   Median :19.05   Median :11.36  
 Mean   : 9.549   Mean   :408.2   Mean   :18.46   Mean   :12.65  
 3rd Qu.:24.000   3rd Qu.:666.0   3rd Qu.:20.20   3rd Qu.:16.95  
 Max.   :24.000   Max.   :711.0   Max.   :22.00   Max.   :37.97  
      medv      
 Min.   : 5.00  
 1st Qu.:17.02  
 Median :21.20  
 Mean   :22.53  
 3rd Qu.:25.00  
 Max.   :50.00  


Let’s take a look at the distribution of our response variable, medv (median house values)

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data=mydata, aes(x=medv))+
  geom_histogram(fill="blue") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of median house values")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.





Note that this is a unimodal distribution, with most home values hovering around 20.
Now let’s look at one of the possible predictors of median house values, crime rate, and how that relates to the median house values in a scatterplot

ggplot(data=mydata, aes(x=crim, y=medv))+
  geom_point()




For this specific case, there appears to possibly be an inverse relationship between house value and crime, but it is hard to tell since so many of the houses have a crime value of 0 or near to 0. Interestingly, it appears that there are no instances of high median house value (>30) that have any crime value over 10.
To identify some other potential variables, let’s run a full correlation on the dataset with median house value. From there, we can pick out the top 5 or so features by absolute value correlation score to include in our linear prediction model.

correlation <- cor(mydata)
medv_correlation <- correlation[,ncol(correlation)]
medv_correlation <- sort(abs(medv_correlation), decreasing = TRUE)
medv_correlation

     medv     lstat        rm   ptratio     indus       tax       nox      crim 
1.0000000 0.7376627 0.6953599 0.5077867 0.4837252 0.4685359 0.4273208 0.3883046 
      rad       age        zn       dis      chas 
0.3816262 0.3769546 0.3604453 0.2499287 0.1752602 


The top 5 values are lstat, rm, ptratio, indus, and tax. Let’s now make a linear model predicting medv with these 5 values and see the summary of the model.

model <- lm(medv~lstat + rm + ptratio + indus + tax, data = mydata)
summary(model)


Call:
lm(formula = medv ~ lstat + rm + ptratio + indus + tax, data = mydata)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-14.2469  -3.0629  -0.9032   1.7415  30.3402 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 17.517713   3.974975   4.407 1.28e-05 ***
lstat       -0.559005   0.048846 -11.444  < 2e-16 ***
rm           4.625169   0.430651  10.740  < 2e-16 ***
ptratio     -0.876154   0.125376  -6.988 8.94e-12 ***
indus        0.056975   0.052699   1.081   0.2802    
tax         -0.003537   0.002128  -1.662   0.0971 .  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 5.225 on 500 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6804,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6772 
F-statistic: 212.9 on 5 and 500 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Home
text:
Hi! My name is Cedric Martinez and I am an Advanced Data Analytics student at the University of North Texas, currently planning on graduating in Spring 2024. I am also currently working full-time as a Technology Analyst with American International Group and received my undergraduate degree in Computer Science from the University of Texas at Dallas. I have experience working with machine learning technology and have a passion for leveraging data science techniques and tools to provide business value by creating recommendations for business improvements by analyzing industry data.
If you would like to reach out to me for potential job opportunities, please contact me at my email: CedricMartinez@my.unt.edu. Thank you!

title: Welcome!
text: Hi, my name is Cedric Martinez and I am a data scientist looking for opportunities for career advancement working with data to provide business recommendations by leveraging the power of machine learning! I have experience working with Python, SQL, and R.
